title: RS22438
content: Since the mid-1950s, Congress has added provisions to the Public Health Service Act (PHSA) for education and training programs in health, medicine, and nursing. Title VII and Title VIII of the PHSA offer grants, scholarships, and loans to individuals and institutions to increase the supply of healthcare professionals. Title VII supports primary care physicians, dentists, public health, and allied health professionals, while Title VIII focuses on nursing education and workforce programs. The Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) administers Title VII and Title VIII programs, with discretionary funding provided in the annual appropriations act. The FY2010 appropriations for Title VII and Title VIII programs total $498.0 million, with additional funds available from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) amended Title VII and Title VIII of the PHSA to revise existing authorities or create new ones. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) amended Title VII and Title VIII of the PHSA to revise existing authorities or create new ones. Implementation of the discretionary programs authorized in PPACA will depend on future appropriations actions. This report summarizes the appropriations history for Title VII and Title VIII programs from FY2001 through FY2010, along with the FY2011 President's budget request. Appendices provide details about plans to distribute ARRA funds and sections of PPACA that amend Title VII and Title VIII of the PHSA. Enacted in March 2010, statutory authorities for Title VII and Title VIII programs had been amended multiple times since their initial passage. The most recent reauthorizing legislation was the Health Education Partnerships Act of 1998, authorizing appropriations through FY2002. The Nurse Reinvestment Act of 2002 extended appropriations authority for some Title VIII programs through FY2007. In the 111th Congress, provisions of PPACA added, eliminated, or revised program authorities in Title VII and Title VIII, including new or extended authorization of appropriations. President Obama's FY2011 budget requested $503.9 million for Title VII and Title VIII programs. The FY2011 budget requested $503.9 million for Title VII and Title VIII programs, an increase of $5.9 million from FY2010. In FY2009, regular appropriations of $392.7 million were provided, with an additional $200 million from ARRA allocated to Title VII and Title VIII programs. President Obama's FY2011 budget request includes $260.0 million for Title VII programs, with an increase of $5.9 million from FY2010. Most ARRA funds are available for obligation over two fiscal years, with $68.2 million obligated in FY2009 and $131.8 million for FY2010. Table 1 shows Title VII appropriations for health training programs from FY2001 to FY2010. Total annual appropriations for Title VII programs fluctuated significantly from FY2001 to FY2010, ranging from $145.1 million in FY2006 to $308.4 million in FY2003. Despite attempts by the George W. Bush Administration to cut funding, Congress generally restored it. Some programs were eliminated in FY2006 but received renewed funding in FY2010. President Obama's FY2011 budget requested $243.9 million for Title VIII programs, maintaining funding levels for six authorized programs. Table 2 displays Title VIII appropriations for nursing programs from FY2001 to FY2010. Title VIII appropriations for nursing programs increased by 104% from FY2001 to FY2009, reaching $171.0 million. In FY2010, Congress further boosted funding by 43%. The Public Service Announcements program authorized in P.L. 107-205 received no funding. Total appropriations for Title VII and Title VIII programs from FY2001 to FY2010 are compiled in Table 3, including President Obama's FY2011 budget request. Appendix A details HRSA's planned obligations of $200 million in ARRA funding over FY2009 and FY2010, while Appendix B summarizes changes in health care reform legislation affecting Title VII and Title VIII. It also mentions sections of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act that amend these authorities.
